narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The effects of sociology on health
I learned about health and healthcare in the modern age.
None, don't take this class
the role of inequality in healthcare
Sociology was new to me so sociological approaches especially as it relates to health. I learned a lot of ways of thinking about why things happen and why things are the way they are.

I learned a lot about the sociological context surrounding medicine. I learned how to analyze sociological data and look for sociological trends. I learned how to view common issues in medicine and public health in new lights, forcing me to re-evaluate my assumptions.
Learned about how we balance biological and social factors in the construction of illness.
Applying sociological concepts to health and illness. Learned underlying causes of health inequality in the US and why it persists.
I learned about the different ways to approach public health problems and how different frames can change both the way a problem is perceived and how it is addressed.
Really interesting info
I learned more about global health challenges
I learned a lot about healthcare and public health through a sociological lens
An understanding of health in terms of sociology framing, using AIDS/HIV and obesity epidemic as case studies.

I learned about the relationship between health, social determinants of health, and the emergence of social movements. I gained insight in how the underlying system and radicalized status can impact things like obesity and health outcomes.
I gained an introduction to sociology and health and illness through a sociological lens. It was a good way to decide whether or not I wanted to be a sociology major or not.

This was my first sociology class ever so I learned a lot of important skills within the discipline of the social sciences, and I learned a lot about how inequality can manifest itself through illness and vice versa.
not much
Learned a lot about health and illness from a sociological context
I learned about different aspects of the U.S. healthcare system, social determinants of health, biomedicalization, HIV/AIDS, etc.

The overall content of this course was very interesting especially because it was a more social/historical/racial approach to analyzing the healthcare system. The readings were interesting and matched the current topics that we spoke about in prior lectures. I was able to learn quite a lot about healthcare in a social context.
Understanding health from a sociological perspective, in that a lot of the concepts and frameworks I learned were knew to me and differed from my previous knowledge of public health
I was able to learn more about health inequalities which I think is important.
The fundamentals of the public health, which touches upon very interesting concepts of medical ethics, patient activism, hospitals, insurance policies.
Learned about the complexity of the U.S. healthcare system, its successes and pitfalls. Learned about how to successfully execute a public health intervention and the fundamental causes of diseases.
I polished up my understanding of terms/concepts in the world of health policy and systems, as well as learned how sociologists name and frame such concepts.

This course taught me about the American healthcare system where I learned about the healthcare system through a sociological perspective and public health perspective. I was able to draw on the course concepts learned in class and apply them to a different topic through a group project for the course. In addition to learning general history of healthcare in America, I learned about how different socioeconomic factors come into play to determine the health of individuals.
How to understand health as a social phenomenon

I learned about health and illness seen through a sociological lens, and all of the implications that come with this. I also learned about the history of some health and illness in the social world. Lastly, I learned about public health interventions.
Learned a lot of sociological concepts related to the health care field.
I learned more about the sociological aspects of health policy, including specific terminology and field specific methods for evaluating how health is studied and produced.
Data and knowledge on health disparities globally and how they occur due to social determinents of health, poverty, structural violence, etc.

I learned the basics of sociology and gained an understanding of the social and environmental factors that determine health outcomes. I was able to learn how to collect and analyze data, conduct interviews, and synthesize information in a research paper format and a public health intervention.
insight on healthcare

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There was not a lot of help given for the first paper
Sections were not helpful in going over content.
Weaknesses = anne taylor
I really enjoyed the course. No complaints
I loved how the projects were somewhat flexible and the class itself was engaging. The open office hours were something I took advantage of and Professor M is really helpful

Strengths - The material was fascinating. The readings weren't too difficult nor tedious, and lecture was highly engaging.

Weaknesses - The group project that the course is structured around is a bit dull. I wish we had had the opportunity to view other chronic illnesses (e.g. AIDS) under the same light as opposed to solely obesity. It felt like a lot of time to work on the same topic, and a few too many components to be worthwhile. Also, if you got paired in an inadequate group, you were stuck for the whole semester.
Lectures were really engaging and interesting. Usually section lined up well with readings and lectures. I enjoyed that the readings were actually helpful in understanding class.
Perhaps a greater focus on introducing general sociological concepts in the beginning of class/explaining how to write sociologically.
The lectures were not super engaging and the instructions for the essays and other assignments weren't clear so it was hard to figure out what was being asked of you.
First essay was graded really hard for an intro class. Was tough to bounce back
Better grading system

I liked that there was discussion section for this class because I thought it made the class even more engaging. I also liked the format of the different graded assignments. I also really liked the guest lecturers.
Strengths: This class was wonderful! The lectures were very well-structured and went perfectly with the readings. The professor was very passionate and knowledgable about the topics.

Strengths: good lecture, I liked the projects/readings

Weaknesses: harsh grading on the first paper with little instruction on what they were looking for, lectures went online so not many people went to class, I wish we had gone deeper into topics

Strengths- accommodating professor, relatively laidback quizzes, responsive professor
weaknesses- readings are overwhelming and although they're super valuable, the reality is that many Yale students don't have the time to read numerous readings for every class. I took 5 classes this semester, and would often feel paralyzed when it came time to do all of the readings, and I think that most of my peers felt similarly.

Strength: the course content is very relevant to daily life and I learned a lot about the world around me. Weakness: sometimes it felt we were just sitting in lecture with minimal engagement with the course concepts until the essays and projects happened (and there were only a few of these). I think that this could be improved by making the discussion section more engaging and small-group-discussion-based.

The content of this course was interesting but I don't feel that it was well-organized. The first few assignments of the year were frustrating in that for the first essay for example, barely any prompt and absolutely no rubric were provided, and the grading was very harsh. The quizzes also seemed to contain questions that were hyper-focused on small details and specificities mentioned in lectures/reading, which would have been fine except that the actual questions on the quiz were not even written with enough precision to be able to come to such a specific answer. Many of the lecture slides were confusing with little connection between slides or repetition of a phrase or sentence without context to ground it in. The whole class just felt very imprecisely organized while also requiring us to know details or perform on essays to such a high level of precision.

strength: cool subject matter
weakness: every assessment was attempted to trick you.
Course material is engaging, but strictness/grading style of teaching fellows varies greatly

Strengths: as someone interested in global health, this course pushed me to really try and think critically about the sociological facets to health, and how such phenomena are reflected in human experiences. I think the course structure reflected this as well, as each assignment appeared to build off of the next, with a central goal in mind for an intervention. 
Weaknesses: none really, maybe balancing out or isolating more critical readings from/with more optional ones, as there might have been more readings than what could be handled for an average week during the semester. In addition, although achievable, group projects were just not as ideal, especially in the final projects of the course, when students are most busy and have varying schedules.
I don't think there are weaknesses and strengths I think it is the course material.
Professor Menon and my TA was amazing, very passionate about the subject

Weaknesses:
Course was very broad and failed to give palpable solutions to the challenges discussed in class.
Strengths:
Great assigned readings and lectures. The professor was very engaging.

Professor was a great lecturer and you could tell that she put a lot of effort into making this class an amazing learning environment for her students. My problem lies with the TFs and the way in which they communicated to us. In my opinion and experience, the TFs made her job as a professor a lot harder, and I will expound on this harsh statement a little later.

The strengths for the course is the feedback from the assignments. Professor Menon was very clear about grading and often encouraged us to try harder and show improvement which was very encouraging to continue trying harder despite getting lower grades on some assignments. The teaching staff was also very accommodating and made the class accessible for students with little sociology background. The weakness for the course is that the lecture slides were too brief and I often wanted more information to be displayed on the slides because I can't always write down everything the professor says out loud.
Nothing Alka Menon is the goat and every lecture was a delight to attend. Readings and lecture material are always super well organized and relevant to each other

Strengths:
- Interesting 
- Thought provoking
- Clear
- Organized
- Taught at a good pace

Weaknesses:
- Discussion sections differed a lot in helpfulness

Loved the content and lectures were very interesting. The assignments, including the group presentation and project, were not my favorite. I think a good alternative would be to write about your personal experinces with the concepts we learned each week for a grade. The intervention stuff was just not very engaging.
The lecture format of the course was well supported by discussion sections, though I would have appreciated lecture recordings being available earlier in the year.
weakness: group projects are unfair in the amount of work students have to do, very into ERM class so really nothing super provoking or in depth

Strengths: Great lectures, great slides 
Weaknesses: More info on how sociological papers should be written
Strengths of this course include the readings, documentaries, and podcast episodes that enabled a real world immersion in the construction of health and illness in the modern day.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you care about healthcare
I would recommend this course to people who have a little background in sociology.

No I would never recommend this course to another student, it was an extreme waste of time! Section was particularly horrendous, anne taylor did not know what was going on & could never answer our questions, not pleasant
Yes -- It was extremely interesting and all of the lectures were very engaging.
Yes, this course is so important
yes

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in working in the healthcare industry. It brings up a lot of valuable points and key food for thought that should not be brushed over. Professor Menon is a gem, too.
Definitely. Especially for premed students who take a heavy science workload. This perspective of social context is really important for medical and public health practitioners.

I think if you are interested in the field then yes this is a great class. It's not too difficult and the readings are fairly interesting. You will learn a lot about the perception of health and illness as well as the healthcare system. However, I wouldn't say this class was super revolutionary or eye-opening. Its a good intro-course.
Yes if youre interested in topic
yes because its a good intro class to learning more about health
yes I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they are interested in science / global health and looking to explore the sociological side of that kind of material!

Yes! This class was crazy interesting. You learn so much about healthcare systems around the world, healthcare organizations (CDC, WHO, etc.), and important sociological topics, which can be applied beyond healthcare. I highly recommend.
Yes, if they are looking for a basic overview.

Yes! The information taught in this class is extremely valuable, and I think that EVERYONE could benefit from the content that's covered in this class. Prior to taking this class, I understand that lower socioeconomic status was correlated with worse health outcomes, but I didn't realize how complex and truly deep-rooted these inequalities are. Even in my day-to-day life I catch myself looking at some situations differently and having a lot more empathy for others since now I understand a bit more about how particular communities have been so marginalized. To really achieve a more equitable world, I think everyone should learn the material in this class.
Yes! Would recommend, it's a great introduction to sociology as way to view the world.
I would not necessarily recommend this course to another student just because I don't feel like it was well-organized or graded kindly.
no

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in learning a little bit about health because it offers a sociological lens into how health works and discusses health frames. It was extremely interesting, and this was my favorite class of the semester.
Yes, if you want to take an interesting sociology class/5th credit.
I would recommend to a first year or sophomore student who is interested in learning more about American healthcare. If you're an upperclassmen, you've probably learned most of this content already.
I would if you're interested in the material. One thing to be aware of is that you should be able to have some sociological background to get a good grade on your essays.

Yes, mainly if they have a more niche interest in the interface of social sciences with health. Be mindful that the course doesnt come without a lot of effort and time in studying for quizzes and group projects. When mid-semester feedback reflected some students dissatisfaction with the course structure up until that point, however, the professor and teaching team were quick to adjust to and truly incorporate this feedback. Overall, putting in that time to be engaged, attend office hours, and to obtain routine feedback from TFs was necessary to doing well in the course.
Yes I would because I think the material is something everyone should learn at some point.
Yes definitely! Take it, especially if youre interested in public health
Yes, I definitely would!

I really hate to say this, but based on my experience this semester, I would not recommend this course to another student. I would 100% recommend a Professor Menon course, but my experience during section and with the constant moving pieces of this class was so negative that it made me consider not being interested in healthcare at large. This evaluation is really hard for me to write because I am not a negative or pessimistic person, and I made an effort to voice my concerns with both Professor Menon and my TF during the semester. Where Professor Menon was helpful, honest, and understanding, my TF was the exact opposite.
Amazing course!! Everyone should take this  especially if you are considering a future career in anything healthcare-related

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because it provides a brief introduction to what American healthcare really looks like through a sociological perspective. If you are looking to learn about public health through a research standpoint, this course would be best for you. I would highly recommend this course if you are pre-med or looking at any future career in medicine!
Yes!!! All the lectures are so engaging and readings work so well with them. Professor Menon is the only professor I trust to teach the sociology of health because she is extraordinarily based

This course was pretty mid. It was incredibly easy in terms of workload and people stopped showing up to class after a few weeks, but I did not find the content that interesting. I'm not saying the content is boring, but it wasn't for me, and I wished I had chosen a better class because I thought I was wasting my time. The final project of doing a health intervention was a waste of time in my opinion.

I would recommend this course to another student because it teaches you about parts of society that we see and hear about that we don't know the full story behind. It provided me with a greater understanding of health and illness in this world.
Yes, very interesting.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in public health or an introduction to sociology.
No
Great knowledge and crucial info if you want to go into healthcare

Yes, I would recommend this course if a student is interested in the social factors like race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, environment, etc. impact conceptualizations of health and illness in society.
Yes, if you're interested in learning more about the social side of healthcare in the US
yes I learned a lot about health and illness in America and I would recommend this course to those who are interested in an intro to health and society
